div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until June 4, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train docks? via Brindisi or via Marseilles. £19.4.11

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m., for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai)El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

ve Goar informs us that about tea days ago he paid i visit to the Uoiversity accompanied by somi ladies, and was disagreeably impressed by the oondact of some of the day students, whe appeared to be entirely uncontrolled by thei sheikhs—who were conspicuous by their abaeno on this occasion—and by the "Magawareen. Tae demeanour and 'anguage of these yoonj theologians were highly discourteous, and th. entire absence of supervision that was remark ed did not say mnch for the discipline observe* within the walls of Al Azhar. At present we cannot recommend Eu opeai ladies to visit Al Azhar. No impediment wil be placed in their way by the Wakfs Adminij tration, which, naturally enough, does not cart to lose the revenue derived from the sale o tickets of admiesi >n, but their visits oanaotbi productive of any good, and may lead to dis agreeable incidents. Moslems who hold con servative views look on their presence witi disgust, and that the Tabah incident has lef a certain bitterness behind it among oertair olasses canuot be denied. The presence o European ladies in a centre of Moslem COD servatism can only provoke ill-feeling which may vent itself in insulting language or rude conduct towards those who have unwittingly offended against Moslem ideas. Ordinarily the visits of Europeans of both sexes are tolerated —though the visitors are not welcomed with enthusiasm —but at present they are regarded by not a few ,of the inmates, especially the rongh olass of "students," who regard the University as an idlers' dab, as an insalt—the wish being no doubt father to the thought At the same tim°, when we hear that a teacher was recently 'i'.l-advised enough to take the pupils of a German girls' school to visit the University we oannot refrain from expressing our amazement at the utter tactlessness of which edaoated Europeans can be capable. Another unpleasant sign of the times has been the petty persecution, in some caiesthe actual ill-treatment, meted out to the stadeats who were suspected of sympathising with Great Britain during the recent orisis. We hear on good authority that Indian Modems have been compelled to leave Al Azhar owing to the mis- oonduotof their fellow-stadents, notably of the Egyptians, whose sympathy with the Ottoman Empire appears to have effaced the tolerance which Mas*apha Pacha Kamel dsolaresto be one of the ohief virtaes of the Moslem. We are glad to believe that the unrnly students of Al Azhar do not represent the majority of Egyp- tians, and we hope that our "Nationalist" oon- frdres will point ont to these young hotheads whose courses in law and divinity appear to have inspired them only with the "olinm thoologionm," that good manners and tolerancj towards persons who hold different opinions befit scholars and woald-be divines better than valgar rudeness and brutal intolerance. The continuance of snch incidents may compel the Government, however reluctant it may be to interfere with the internal organisation of a venerable and famous University, to take steps that will render the repetition of such mis- oondnet impossible.

div.head: BRITISH EMIGRATION
div.p: A remarkable and most happy change has recently oconrred in the outflow of Britons seeking their fortunes oversea. Up to last year, patriotism had to deplore that snch a large proportion of these self-expatriated sons and daughters of the United Kingdom transferred their personalities to the great Amerioan Republic. Bat the tide has lately changed its direction to a notable extent, and there seems reasonable likelihood that before many years Canada will become the ohief absorbsnt of our surplus population. As compared with 1904, the number who went to the Dominion to earn a better living than they could secure at home showed an increase of nearly 11,000, whereas 24,000 fewer British settlers established themselves in the United States. It is believed, too, that many of the latter t nbsequently crossed the frontier into British North Amerioa, in oompany with thousands of Amerioan oolonists. The same tendency, bat to a mnoh less degree, operated to increase the populations of Australia and New Zealand, while now that their statesmen are striving to attract emigrants instead of repelling them, the tide should set still more strongly towards the lands of the Soathern Cross. Sooth Africa is the one exception to the increase of British immigration, but that is easily acoonnted for; there was snch a rush thither after the Boer war, that the looal labour market has not yet assimilated the too copious supply.

div.head: Armenian Community.
div.p: The Orthodox Armenians of Alexandria have elected ten members of their National Council. Four others will be elected on Sunday next.
Huge Cotton Spinning Profits.

An instance of the remarkably flourishing condition of the Lancashire cotton spinning industry is provided in the report of a firm at Leigh. The company, for somo years past, has paid dividends and bonuses amounting to 15 per cent, per annum. Last week an additional bonus of 25 per cent, was declared.
Wife Murder In Cairo. *

A Sudanese woman was found dead two days ago in the Khalifa quarter of Cairo. The medioal examination showed that the deceased was a mass of wound*, death being due to violent blows with a naboot. The unfortunate woman was identified as the wife of a Sudanese named Belal Bahr, who is s.ispeoted of having ccmmitted the murder.
Argonaut Dinner.

A reunion of the passengers who have made voyages in the steam yacht Argonaut was held last Wednesday at the Great Central Hotel, London, when a oheque of £1,000 was handed to Admiral Sir R/chard Tracey, K.C B., the deputy-chairman of the Seaman's Hospital Sooiety, being the amount subscribed by the passengers, officers, and crew to endow an Argonaut bed in the Dreadnought Hospital.
Alexandria Native Court

The Native Court of A'exandria this morn- ing sentenced Mohamed Ali Malha, a native of Zawiet El Bahr, Kom Hamada Markaz, to imprisonment for life with hard labour, for murdering in May last Az'js El Sayed of the same village ; and sentenced El Bastawissi, Ali Ashmawi, and Bassiouni to one, two, and three years' imprisonment respectively, for destroying a bean-field at Khomara, Etai El- Baroud Markaz, in May last. The criminalsaccompanied by a fourth, who was shot namber of the injured who are suffering from in the field by a ghaffir on resisting arrest. | blood-poisoning, it is believed
Corporation of Western Egypt

Croubhank Pachr, local chairman, and Mr. Beckett, general manager of the Corporation of Western Egypt, retnrned yesterday to Cairo, after a thorough examination of the company's railway from Khargeh Junction, a little north of Farshout, to the Oasis, of which nearly 50 kilometres are completed. The telephone from the Nile Valley to the Khargeh Oasis is alto completed as far as railhead. The progress of the railway is very satisfactory and the Corporation engineers hope to have another 50 kilometres in ranning order by the month of September.
An Empire day Cateohlsm.

An "Empire Day Catichism," for the use o British subjeots, has been drawn up by the Earl of Meath in connection with the growing movement which he founded. In the form of a six page pamphlet, it contains a number of questions and answers on the extent and responsibilities of Empire, on which every citizen might be expected to he informed, but which in reality, probably few fully appreciate. It is a welcome reminder of the world-wide dominion for which the British race has made itself responsible. The watchwords ol the Empire Day movement are "Responsibility, Daty, Self-sacrifice," and its motto. King, one Flag, one Fleet, one Empire.
Presentation at British Consulate.

A very pleasant and quiet ceremony was that which took plaoe yesterday afternoon, when the staff of the British Consulate met together in the room of Mr. E. B. Gould, H.B.M. s Consul- Genera', and presented Mr. W. Chevalier, one of their number, with a beautiful silver oup. Mr Chevalier has just retired from work after a long period of 43 years' service in the Consulate, and the staff desired to recognise the event, and also Mr. Chevalier's unfailing well-chosen words made the presentation, ex pressing the regret he felt at losing the services of an "old friend" and the hope that he woald be long spared to enjoy a happy and well-earned retirement

div.head: THE KHEDIVE. DELIVERS SPEECH TO THE ULEMA.
div.p: Before his departure for Constantinpple yesterday the Khedive received the Ministers and Sir Vincent Corbett. At 3.30 p.m. he put out in a launch, accompanied by the Ministers, the Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent, and the Financial Adviser, for the Austrian Lloyd steamer Afrioa, which was moored seme 300 yards from Ras el Tin. Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, the Governor of Alexandria,MejorHopkinson,and Mr. H. von Pitner, agent of the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Co., received the Khedive on his arrival. Mr. von Pitner showed his Highness over the ship and was cordially thanked for his suocess in securing so comfortable a vessel for the voyage to Constantinople. After conversing for sometime with those present the Khedive bade farewell and at 4.15 p.m. the steamer pat oat to sea. The Khedive, yesterday morning, summoned number of Ulema to Ras-el-Tin Palaoe and addressed them, stating that the Ulema should join in aiming at virtaoas objeots, and should advise Moslems to follow tbeir example, showing the nation the value of religions observances, and adopting ths best methods for spreading knowledge of the law and science among the people. The Ulema of Egypt, said his Highness, mast be the first of all theMohamedan religious leaders throughout the world, the more so since Egypt is situated in the centre of the Moslem world and its people are the most conversant with the Arabic tongue. His Highness referred to the differences which had reoently occurred among the Ulema of Alexandria, pointing out that they led to many prejudicial results, some of which his Highness mentioned. In adddition to religions instruction, oontinaed the Khedive, it was necessary to enlighten the soul of the student and strengthen the will, and this training of the character wonld improve the morality and the ability of the nation. His Highness premised to do his best to support the Ulema fiuauoially. After his speech the Khedive conferred the Order of the Medjidieh of the 2nd olaas on Sheikh Mohamed Shaker, president of the Ulema Board of Alexandria, in recognition of his valuable services, and the deooration was handed to the Sheikh in the presence of the other Ulema.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH
div.p: A RUMOUR DENIED. A rumour having been oironlated in Berlin that Dr. Von Bergmann's visit to Constantinople was not to examine the Sultan's daughter, but to perform an operation on the Sultan himself, a "Tribune" correspondent saw his Excellency's son, who is also a doctor. He stated that there was absolutely no troth in the rnmoar, and that his father had gone to Constantinople with a private assistant to operate for appendioitis on the sixteen-year- old daughter of the Sultan by his favourite and principal wife.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: LORD CROMER'S SCHEME.
HOW IT HAS BEEN RECEIVED.

A rumour has been afloat to the effect that owing to the opposition with which Lord Cromer's soheme has met for the creation of an International Assembly in Cairo, his lordship has deoided not to pnrsne his idea any farther. We are in a position to state that this rumour is absolutely unfounded. The preliminary stage of the career of Lord Cromer's project, namely, that oonneoted with the ascertaining of the feeling entertained towards it by the different European communities in Egypt, has exceeded in results his lordship's most sanguine expectations, and constitutes the greatest encouragement to proceed with it. No expression of opinion from the Govern-ments concerned one way or another has reached his lordship, who has not sought it yet,, but it is reasonable to suppose that they will allow themselves to be largely influenced by the body of their nationals on the spot, who, as we have said, have received Lord Cromer's idea very favourably Therefore the prospects of an International Assembly in Egypt comiug into existenoe are, jadging by the present state of things, very fair.

div.head: THE TORPEDO-BOAT DISASTER.
div.p: RESULT OF COURT-MARTIAL. The result of the oonrt-martial on the survivors of torpedo boat No. 56, held in Malta, is that Lieutenant Lionel Maitlaod Addison loses one year's seniority and is ssverely reprimanded and dismissed his ship ; Gunner Pnddifoot is severely reprimanded and dismissed his ship, aud the remainder are acquitted. The officara of H. M. S. Arrogant are totally acquitted of blame. The Minerva and Diana retnrned to Malta from Port Said on Saturday last and went into dock.

div.head: TELEGRAPH TO EL ARISH.
div.p: Mr. Wallioh, Inspector General of the State Telegraphs, has returned from Suez. Telegraphic communication has now been established between Suez and Nakhl, and Nakhl and El Arish.

div.head: CHANGES IN NIGERIA.
div.p: Reuter's Agency states that the Emir of Gando, an important centre to the south of Sokoto, who was proved to have promised assistance to the rebels in the recent Sokoto rising, and whose attitude was altogether unsatisfactory, has been deposed by the High Commissioner, and deported with certain members of his household to Lokoja. A new Emir has been appointed in his stead. It is ander contemplation to remove the ex-Emirs of Kano and Z»ria to Barnto. There are rumours of unrest in the Province of Bauchi, and also of a Sennssi gathering to the north of Lake Chad. A fort is being built at Burmi, near which place, if the Sennssi movement comes to anything, trouble may be expected to arise

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: T. E. the Ministers will return to Cairo this evening. Ibrahim Pacha Faad, Minister of Jastice, has arrived at the Palast-Hotel Furstenhof, Marienbad. ~ Fakhry Pacha, Minister of Public Instruo tion, will leave for Earope on the 26th inst. His Excellenoy intends to divide his holiday between England and France.nite de 1'adoption da systkme de destraotear Lord Cromer to-day visited the teftiche of employe au Caire et qui paralt avoir de bona the Agricultural and Industrial Company at | rdsultata dans cette ville. Ls destrnctenr à Ahon Matamir, Behera. Sir William Garstin, Adviser to the Ministry ofPublic Works, will leave for England on the 16th inst. At Commemoration at Oxford University on the 20th inst., it is proposed to confer the honorary degree of DCL. upon Vieooont Milner, G.C.B..G.C.M.G. Others who are to be honoured with this degree are: His Exoalleocy Wang Tahsieh, the Chinese Minister in London ; Sir John Madden, K.C.M.G., Chief Jastice of the Sapreme Court of Viotoria, and Chanoellor of the Melbourne University ; the Earl of Aberdeen, G.C.M.G.. Lord Lieutenant of Ireland ; Mr. Haldane, K.C., M.P., Secretary for War, and Sir Horace Curzon Plankett, F.R.S.In a Convocation of Oxford University held last week in the 8heldonian Theatre, presided over by the Vice-Chancellor (the Rev. Dr. Merry).the honorary degree of Doctor of Soience was oonferred upon Captain H. G. Lyons, R.E. retired, F.RS., Director-General Survey Department of Egypt. Dr. Lyons was introdnoed by Professor Love. The Vice-Chancellor and Proctors have appointed Sheikh Mohamed Hasanein Al- Ghamrawi as University Teacher of Arabic at Oxford for two years. The Emperor William has oonferred the Ordre pour le Alerite on Professor Koch, who is now in East Afrioa, conducting investigations regarding the sleeping sickness. Kaimakam Cobbe mandant, Alexandria leave on the 11th inst. Bey, City Assistant Com- Polioe, goes on. Captain the Hon. W. A. Trefnsis, Scots Gaards, lately serving with the Egyptian forces, is retiring from the Army. Captain Frederick Samael Inglefield, a Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty, and Aide de- Camp to the King, who has been appointed Rear-Admiral, was born in 1854. He entered the Navy in 1868, and beoame captain in Jane 1895. He was a lieutenant in the Minotaur during the Egyptian war in 1882, and also in the Condor during the operations in the Sudan and Saakin in 1884-85. He was subsequently appointed assistant direotor of naval intelligence and a Lord Commissioner of the Admiralty. Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy H >tel, Port Said, we notice : Msjor Percy 8mith, Nungovioh Bey and family, Mr. Wild and family, Mr. Bel tram, Mrs. Milward, Maitre Carton de Wiart, Mr. W. B Pickering, Soutrau Bey Muscat, Mr. Sursock, Mr. Guy Eden, Mr. Tomasoelli, Miss A. Beansire, Miss Shortland, Mr. and MmoMngnenat, Mr. E E Peach, Mr. A. Lodenstrom, Mr. S. Schmidt, Mr. Monari, Mr. Be'faoti, Mr. Vylands, Mr.Ford, Mr. B.S. Seed and family.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Commission Manioipale s'est rdanie le 6 juin 1906 à 4 h. p. m. aa palais municipal sons la prdsidence de M. le Dr. Sohisss Pacha. Communication est d node d'une lettre du 27 mai 1906 de S. E. le Ministre del'Intdrienr demandant de tenir en suspens la vente de la parcelle N° 27 des terrains des quais, cette paroelle appartenant pre qne ent'rement an Gouvernement et ne fa is ant pas partie des terrains gagnds sur la mer. L'Administrateur dit qu'k la suite de cette lettre des avis roctificatifsont 4t4 publics dans les jonrnanx. Aprks an ^change d'iddes, la Commission oonsiddrant que catte parcelle fait partie d'un ensemble de lots et qne l'dventualitd d'nne oopTopridtd de 1'Etat ne sanrait 6tre un obstacle à la vente, la Municipality et l'Etat ponvant s'entendre ultdriearement sur l'attri- bation da produit de la vente, ddoide de demander au Gouveruemeut de permettre la mise en ven^e de la paroelle en question, en m6me temps que oelles poor lesqnelles des avis ont 4t4 ddjk publics. Communication est dgalement donnde d'une lettre da 2 juin 1906 de S E. le Ministre de l'lntlriear approuvant les divers orddits vot4s par la Commission dans sa sdanoe da 23 mai 1906. A oe sojet le Ministre estime qao ceax de ces orddits qui ont 4td pr^levds sar le prodait des ventes de terrains ne devront 6tre employes qu'aa far et k mesare que ce? ventes auront 4t4 effdetudes et que le prix eu aura 4t4 versd à la caisse manioipale. Le prodait de oes ventes de mfime que les ddpenses aaxqaelles cette ressoarce est affec- tde devront figarer respeotivement an orddit et aa debit do budget extraordinaire. La Commission en prend note : Lectare est donnde d'aue lettre da 2 jain 1906 de S. E. le Ministre de l'lntdrieur approuvant les decisions prises par la Commission tendant k prelever sar le fonds de l'emprnnt la somme de L.E. 7.400 montant des expropriations impnWes sar le budget extraordinaire d'aprks une pr4o4dente decision et à majerer de L.E. 22 le orddit de LE. 185 precedemment vote pour l'arndnagement des kiosqaes du service des Recettes. Mention en faite de l'envoi aux membres du procks verbal de la seance des Comites d'hy- gikne et de3 travaux publics reanis aa sojet de la question d'installation d'nn destraotear pour les immondices de la ville. Les deux Comites ont ooncla k l'opporta- installer devrait avoir 6 oellu'e', sauf à en angmenter plus tard le nombre an far et à mesare des ndce3sit4s. Ls co fit de premikre installation serait d'environ 10503 L E. Eu oe qui conoerne l'emplacsment, les Comitks prk- fkrent le fixer sur l'antre rive du oanal Mah- moudieh k proximitk da pont projetk du cd$6 de Karmoas. Les Comitks pensent enfin qae ktant donnk le caraotkre alkatoire des bkndfices resultant du destraotear, il ne sanrait 6tre question de le oonfiar à l'entreprise privke. Ils recommandent enfin qae des dtades mfiries soient entreprises tant aa point de vae des frais d'iastallation que d'entretieu annaels, et que le service matte à l'ktude la question des expropriations à faire pour l'acqaisition des terrains ndoessaires non senlement ponr le destrnotenr mais 4galement ponr le transfert dventuel des 4oniiss mnnioipales et du ddpdt de la voirie dans une mdme zone, le terrain à rerver à oet effet devant 6tre assez vaste ponr servir kla construction d'habitations ponr les OQvriers de la Municipality. Aprks an 4ohange d'id4es, la Commission adopte les conclusions des Comit4s et decide de proc4der anx 4tades definitives sar les bases ynonceeadins ces conclusions, Vu le depart en conge de quelquea membres de la Delegation, il est procede a l'eieotion de 3 unmbrei provisoires pour oe oollkge. MM. Ralli, Barbaza et Gherianni Bey sont nommes an serntin secret. M. Rieti eit nomme an soratin secret, mem- bre sopp'.eant provisoire aa Conseil da Tanzim darant l'absence en conge de M. Stress.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (AujourdChui d midi et demie) Marche trfcs calme, les oonrs s'affaiblissent encore. L'agricole perd 1/16 à 9 5/8. La National recule de 3/16 à 25 3/4. La Delta Light reste stationnaire à 12. Les Tramways d'Alexandrie dividendesga gnent 2 f.50 à 330. La Daira s'alourdit à 17. La Crown Brewery est iuchangee à 208. La Salt & Soda tombe à 20/9 en baisse de 3 penoe sur hier. L'Obligation Credit Foncier 1886 faiblit de 0 50 à 324 1/9, la nouvelle reste à 270 1/2. La Cassa di Soon to est en baisse de 2 f.50 à 211 1/2. La Delta Land reaotionne à 3 25/32. Par oontre les Saoreries a van cent de 1 f.50 26 1/2. L'Egyptian Investment et a 19/32 les Trust et les Estates quoique echanges cloturent à leurs conrs d'hier. Le marohe, à Liverpool, etant ferme domain et aprks domain, la Boarse d'Alr-xandrie le seia egalement dorant oes deux jours.

div.p: {Communication Officielle} La Dklkgation Manioipale s'eat rkanie le 5 jain 1906 à 5 h. p.m. sons la prksidence de M. le Dr Sohiess Pacha. Presents : MM. Ahmed Paoha Jehia, Stli- man bey Abani, Dr. G. Valensin, G. Zervuda- ohi, membre', W. P. Chataway, admiuistra tear, J. Sedky bey lecrktaire. La Municipality ayant demandk aa Syndicat des Sooiktks d'Assuranoes s'il ktait dispose de prendre à sa charge one lkgkre dkpcnse de L.E. 300 poor l'achat d'extincteurs, delinks à porter des secoars immkdiat?, en attendant le fonotionnement des pompes, le Syudicat it forme qo'il regrette de ne ponvoir intervenir dans ces frais. La Dyiygation dycide de rkpon- dre qn'elle renonce dans ces conditions à l'achat de ces eztinctenrs dont l'emploi aorait yty pins partioulikrement profitable aux ditea Sooiktks. La Dyiygation sor rappr rt du Comity spkcial, arrkte le programme des rnelles k paver cette annke avec les vieilles dalles existant au dkpftt. Elie demandera à la Commission l'onvertnre des crkdits sopplkmentaires snivants : 1. LE. 60, à pryiever ear le budget extraordinaire pour la confection de plaques poor le* oharrettes à main et les bicyolette?. 2. L.E. 418 k pryiever sur la ryserve du budget ordinaire poor imprimks et fournitures de bureau. 3. L E. 3C0 à pryiever sur la meme ryserve poor seconrs aux employks licenciks pour ma- ladie on aux families d'employks dkckdks. Se Tyferant k une demande du Gonvernorat, la Dyiygation considkre qu'il agpartient à la police de prendre les dispositions vonlues poor assurer le sanvetage des personnes en danger de se noyer, les dispositions intyressant snrtont la sycnrity pnbliqne. La Municipality ne sanrait dono intervenir dans la question qu'au point de vuedu prinoipe d'ane subvention pour l'achat des engine de sanvetage, subvention qo'il appartiendra à la Commission de fixer. La Dyiygation adjuge à M. Moscatelli au prix de LE. 115 les travaux de canalisation depuis le Rond Point juequ'k la prison de Hadra. Elie prend note de di verses lettres do Ministkre del'Intkriear approuvant les crydits votks par la Commission dans sa syance du 23 mai, ainsi que le prklkvement sur l'emprunt des dypenees d'expropriation. La Dyiygation prend acte d'une lettre de la Compagnie des Tyiyphonea informant qa'elle mettra sous pea à la disposition du public des formulesimprimyes pour les rydamations. Elie dyoide de consacrer L.E. 200 à la rkpa- ration de l'asphaltage de la rue Abdel Moneim ainsi qoe le macadamisage des rue Cogniard et Abou Nawatir k Ramleh. Adoptant une proposition du service technique, la Dyiygation dycide d'exyouter les travaux de terrassement à entreprendre sur la route de trente mktres depuis la route de Chatby jaequ'k la tranchye de l'lbrahimieh. sur tonte la largeur de la route au lieu de le* faire uniqnement sur la largeur des deux voies de tramways, cornme il avait ktk prkckdemment dkcidk. Elie proposera à la Commission d'accorder le suppiyment de crydit nkcessaire à ce travail, sur le budget extraordinaire. La syance est levye à 7h. 1/2 p.m.

La Banque d'A thknes a cldtnrk à 158. * * * Sur notre marchk des valeurs, la lourdeur qui s'ytait desfinke hier vers la oloture s'est accent060 oe matin, et nous avons à enregistrer des oours plus faibles sur presque to ate la ligne. La National Bank a flkchi à 25 3/4 13/16 et l'Agricole à 9 11/16. La Banque d'Athknes ert revenue à 156. Le Comptoir Financier a rk- trogradk à 5 5/8 Faction ancienne et 5 9/16 la nouvelle. Les Sucreries ont atteint 27 1,2 pour olo- turer outre 26 et 27 francs. * * * Suivant les dernikres informations regies à Alexandrie, le capital de la Banque d'Athknes sera porty de 20 à 40 millions de drachmes par l'kmission de 2)0,000 actions nouvelle?. La moitiy de oas actions, kmises à 150 drachmes, serait utilieke poacl'absorption de la Bar qDa de Crydit Indnstriel de Grko?, apres estimation de son actif, msjork de 500,000 drachmes. Ea d'antres termes, le capital nominal de la Banque de Cry lit Industrie!, qui est de 10,000,00 ), serait pris par la Banque d'Athknes pour 10,500,000 draoh. Ces 100,000 actions seraient donnyes aux aotionnaires de la Banque de Crydit à raison de 2 actions nouvelles de 150 drachmes de la Banque d'Athknes pour trois actions de la Bar que do Crydit de ICO drachmes ohacune. Les autre8 100,000 actions seraient offerte? de pryfyrence aux aotionnaires de la Banqne d'Athknes, au meme prix de 150 drachmes. dars la proportion de 1 action nouvelle pour 2 anciennes. L'eusemble de l'opkration donnerait an sur plus de 10 millions de drachmas qui irait grossir la reserve de la Binque d'Athknes et la porterait à plus de 12 millions de drachma-1. La souscription à 5,000 aotions, de £ 4 ohacune, de l'Egyptiau Motor Traction Co. a yty ooverte ce matin à 8 h. 30 k 1'Anglo Egyptian Bank, au Caire et à Alexandrie, et cldtuike à midi. Ce matin a eu lieu ygalement, à la mkme Bar que, la souscription à 4,200 aotions, de £ 4 chaoune, de la Sociyty Gknkrale d'Elec trioitk et de Myoanique, Ainsi que nous l'avons dyjkannoncy, l'Egyp-tiau Motor Traction Co. a yty oonstituye au oapital de £ 60,000 divipy en 15,000 aotion de £ 4 thacune, avec 1,200 parts de fondateur sans dysignation de valeur. La Sociyty Gynyralo d'Eleotricitk et de Mycanique a yty formye avec an oapital de £ 50,000, divisk en 12,500 de £ 4 chaoune, et 4,50) parts de fondateur sans dysignation de valeur. Ces kmpsions sont, apparemment, les der- nikres de la saison. ♦ * * Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les aotionnaires de la Sociyty anonyme des Eaux de Tantah sont informys que, par dkc'- sion de l'assembiye gknkra'e ordinaire du 31 Mai dernier, les coupons ci aprks seront payys, k partir de Lundi 11 Join 1906, à la National Bank of Egypt: Aotion ordinaire: 6 sh. 6 contre le coupon No. 5; aotion de jouissance: 1 sh. 6 contre le ooapon No. 2; part de fondateur: P.E. 7 8/10 oontre le coupon No. 2. * * •jell ressort du dernier ytat oomparatif pnblik par la Sociyty anonyme de la Brasserie des Pyramides qoe la vente de bikre et de glace, dn ler Janvier à fin Mai 1906 a rapportk L E. 9 916 oontre 8,160 pour la pkriode correspon- lante de l'annye passke, soit un surplus de L.E. 1,786 en favour de l'exercice oourant.

div.head: HISTORY OF EGYPT.
div.p: {Continued) One of the most interesting chapters in Professor Breasted's book is that entitled The Religious Revolution of Ikhnaton," in which the progress of religious thought in Egypt is traced and some very interesting comparisons are made with Hebrew ideas. The chapter opens as follows : "No nation ever stood in direr need of a strong and practical ruler than did Egypt at the death of Amenhotep III. Yet she chanced to be ruled at this fatal crisis by a young dreame-, who, in spite of unpreoe dented greatness in the world of ideas, was not fitted to cope with a situation demanding an aggressive man of affairs and a skilled military leader, in fine suoh a man as Thutmose III. Amenhotep IV., the young and inexperience! son of Amenhotep III., and the Queen Tiy, was indeed strong and fearless in certain directions, but he failed nt'erly to understand the practical needs of his empire. "He had inherited a d'ffijult situation. The oorfliot of new forces wi:h tradition was, as wa have seen, already felt by his father. The task before him was such manipulation of these oonfPcting force i as might eventually give reaco -able play to the new and modern tendency, but at the same time to conserve enough of the old to prevent a catastrophe. It was a problem of practical statesmanship, bat Amerhotep IV. sxw it chiefly in its', ideal aspects. His mother, T y, and his queen, Nofretete, perhaps a woman of Asiatic birth, and a favourite p'ieit, Eye, the hasband of his childhood narse, formed his immediate circle. The first two probably exercised a powerful influence over him, and were given a prominent share in the government, at least as fir as its public manifestations were con-cerned, for in a manner quite surpassing his father's similar tendenoy, he constantly appear ed in public with both bis mo'her and his wife. The loftyaod impractical aims which he had in view must have found a ready response in these his two most influential councillors. Thu°, while Egypt was in some need of a vigorous and skilled ad ninistrator, the young King was iu close counsel with a priest and two perhaps gifted women, who, however able, were not of the fibre to show the new Pharaoh what the empire really demanded. Instead cf gathering the army so sadly needed in the Naharin, Amenhotep IV. immersed himself heart and soul in the thought of the time, and the philosophizing theology of the priests was of more importance to him than all the provinces of .Asia. Io such contemplations he gradually developed ideals srd purposes which muke him the most remarkable ot all the Pharaohs and the first individual in human history. The profound influence of Egypt's imperial position had Dot been limited to the externals of life, to the manners and customs of the people, to the rich and prolifio ar*-, pregnant with new possibilities of beauty, bat had ex tended likewise to the thought of the age. Soch thoaght was chiefly theological and we must divert it of all the ideas which are con- Eo*ed by the modern term 'the thought of the age.' Even before the conquests in Asia the priests had made great progress in the interpretation of the gods and they had now reached a stage in which, like the later Greeks, they were importing semi-philosophical significance iuto the myths such as those had of oourse not originally possessed." How far the author is justified in saying that this significance was imported by prieets miy be questioned. It is now a well-recognised and established fact that there is a deep meaning in these ancient myths which have survived from time immemorial and appear often as Bible narratives in the sacred writings of various religious sects, — Hebrew included. We need not instance these ; they are too well-known to the Biblical student to require recapitulation, A great advanoe in thought had been reached when, as the author ay8, "the Egyptian had gained the idea of a single controlling intelligence behind and above all sentient beings, including the gods. The efficient force by which this intelligence put hia designs into execution was his spoken "word," and this primitive "logos" is undoubt-edly the incipient germ of the later logos- doctrine which found its origin in Egypt. In the times to come when research shall have completed the revelations of the past, now only as it were in their infanoy, anoier-t Egypt bids fair to stand foremost as the country where religious 'conceptions of the highest inspiration had their origin. We have only space to notice the similitude of thought in two poems entitled "Praise of Aton by Kinglkhnatcn and Queen Neferneficia ton" and the 104th Psalm of the Hebrews. These are given in para'lel passages in the book with striking effect, thas : PSALM 104. 0 lord, how manifold are thy works ! In wisdom hast thou made them all ; The earth is full thy creatures. HYMN TO ATON. How manifold are all thy works ! They are hidden from tefore us. 0 thou sole god, whose power no other pos -e'setb. i'hou didst create the earth according to thy desire. The above is but one illustration out of many j and we way mention, too, that the Messianic idea is introduced in such a manner an to lead the author to say ' we cannot reriit the conclusion that it furnished the Hebrew prophets with the farm ; and to a surprising extent also with the content of Messianic prophecy. It remained for the Hebrew to give this old form a higher ethical and religions s grpfioance." „ , ... , We hope that Dr. Breasted's work will be ex4ensively read and quoted, in view of the valual fa information it gives respecting this * p derfol lar d of Egypt A Hidtory Of Egypt from the Earliost Times to the ' by James Henry Breasted, Egyptology and Oriental History jn t'uiverxity of Chicago, o'nbiiijr i Sons. Price 85.

div.head: NAVAL PUNISHMENTS
div.p: Now that the use of the "oat" has been suspended in the Navy one of the most ancient punishments meted ont to unrnly seamen has passed into the list of things that have been. In the earlier days of the history of the Navy some trivial offences were brntal in the extreme, and they were certainly not all recognised by the "Bkck Book of the Ad-miralty." This historical book was popolarly, but erroneously, supposed .to be a register of the delinquencies of Naval officers set down with more or less accuracy by an Admiralty clerk. As a matter of fact, it was a code of maritime laws and customs, introduced from the laws of Oferou by Richard I. It was lost in the early part of the nineteenth century, and a fresh oode compiled with much labour from various manuscripts in the British Museum. The laws of 0'^ron provided, among other punishments, one that later beoame keelhauling. The marinor was forbidden to remove his clothes, except when in a port far wintering, and the penalty far disobedience was that far each offence he was to be plunged into the sea from the yardarm three times, and after the third offence he was to forfeit his pay and any share he bad in the freight of the ship. In a volume published in 1685 we get farther information on the subjeot of punish-ments. It appears to have been the daty of the boatswain "to see all offenders punctually punished, either at the capstan by the bilboes or with docking at the main-yard-arm." Punishment at theoapstan consisted in lashing the offender to one of the bars with his arms extended and a basket of ballets suspended round his neck. Ducking at the main yard arm is self-explanatory, but the author adds: "If the offence be foul, he is also drawn under the very keel of the ship, which they term keel-raking, and being thas under water, a Great Piece is given fire unto, right over his Head, as well to astonish him with the thunder thereof, which proveth most offensive to him, as to give warning to all others to look ont and beware." Petty pilferings and 'knaveries" of the ships' boys were punished with the rod, nsaally on a Monday morning. The Calender of Domestic State Papers in the time of Charles II. records the punishment awarded to Robert Johnes, boatswain of the "Francis," for embezzling stores. He was ordered to be rowed from Chatham Dockyard to one of His Majesty's ships "with the usual ceremony of drum-beating at the head of the boat, his crime written in capital letters and fixed on his head, breast, and baok ; to stand one boar on the gunwale of the ship with a rope from the yardarm round hia neck, and then to have fifteen strokes on his naked back ; to have the like punishment at Woolwioh and Deptford; to he dismissed his ship, and rendered incapable of ever bearing any office in any of His Majesty's ships." It is small wonder that Monson, Boteler, and other writers inveighed agaiost the oraelty of these punishments. Bat their tirades had no effeot. In 1695, Admiral the Earl of Liudsay issued a code of instructions, in which the summary punishments include docking, fasting, keelhaaling, flogging at the capstan, hanging weights on offenders "till their heart or back be ready to break," or to "gagg or scrape thqir tongues for blasi h?my or swearing." A century later these punishments were still in use, and others, soch as stopping grog, had been added. One punishment that was most dreaded was ducking aoross a crowbar. The offender was tied to a crowbar, which was nicknamed "the chair." This was suspended from the yard- by a rope, and the man let down into the water. The weight of the bar naturally prevented him from being able to float as he could when docked under ordinary circum ataooep, and the docking was, therefore more thorough and much more often fatal. Bat flogging was the staple punishment. Even allowing far the exaggeration of such writers as Jack Nasty face, Ned Ward, and others of their type, we oan be quite sare that the flagging carried on by many of the captains in the eighteenth century was unnecessarily brutal. A ruffiin is quoted by Mr. Man*field in "Sea Life in Nelson's Time" as having once described flogging as "Nothing but an *0' 1 and a few 'Oh ! my God's S' and then you oan put on your shirt." There was was also the punishment of flogging through the fleet, which was much more severe than an ordinary flagging, and was only given for the offences of striking an admiral, a oommodore, or other officer of high rank, or for attempting to escape in circumstances which aggravated the offence Modern punishments are more lenient, though not, we may be sure, less efficacious Cells i»», in fact, the usual punishment for most offenoes. There is a story told of a ehip's oorporal who was food of using long words, and once found a man on the lower deck sconring and polishing one of the steel stanchions in quite a leisurely manner. "Now then," cried the corporal. "You're not polishing that stanchion with sufficient a'acrity." "Course I ain't," replied the blue-jacket, who was very fond of trying to score off his superior?, "I'm a cleaning it with brick and oi'." His little joke co3t him ten days' cell'. The punishment of mast heading is moch less resorted to rowadays. On a cold winter's night it was perhaps, rather a cruel trial to seod a young boy on to the foretopsail yard, but in the summer the delirquent could often get a very pleasant hoar's sleep comfortably seated between the tip blocks. There was a certain captain, win nows holds flag rank, who will probably remember to this day the uurnly set of midshipmen he had in one of his shipp, whom he succeeded in mastheading in spite of the instructions forbidding the punishment. He ordered the offender to the foretop gallant. . masthead to see how many turns there were in anything but encouraging. On Tuesday there the se'zings of the shrond; then when the number had been duly reported he wxs Bent to the spanker gaff end ; then over the bows to the dolphin striker, and so on. By the end of the cruise the occupants of the gun room had been reduced to something like subjection. Another ingenious puuishment wxs invented by a first lieutenant far dealing with men who upset paint, or otherwise made dirty marks on the deck. They ware set to scrub the spot every day for a week with their day's portion of grog, and though the mark had disappeared long before they had done the second sorab. they were kept at it by the oorporal of the watoh, amid the je'rs of their messmates, which ac4ed, perhaps, as a more powerfal deterrent than the loss of the grog.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

Speculation is still rife in the City as to the probable outcome of the interest shown by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in the question ot our Gold Re89rve. That the ^ime is ripe /or action is undoubted, also that the fundamental basis of any action must be "more gold." The City's experiences daring the last six months have clearly demonstrated the absurdity of this market-— the only free market for gold— endeavouring to straggle along with a reserve totally inadequate to its needs. Can it be wondered at, that with a Reserve of about halt that of Germany and a third of that of France, we should he subjeot to violent disturbance on the withdrawal of a few millions 1 Only three days ago the market took alarm on the rancour of the withdrawal of two hundred thousand pounds, and only calmed down on hearing that the report was unfounded. This shows the state of tension which at present existp, and oredit dealers most natarally mark their rates in accordance therewith. Loans to the Stock Exchange over the present aocoQnt commanded 4 f to 5 °/0, weekly loans which throughout the week have stood at about 3 j % still stand at 3 to 3 { %. and oall money is to day quoted 3 to 3 J %. Discount rates have showo a marked steadiness for several days, "short tenors" are not much in demand, the rate for 60-day bills being 3 £ %, whilst 3 months bills can be done at 3 | % and 6 months at 3 | The B ink Return exhibits very little change since last week; notwithstanding the infl ix of gold the total reserve shows a loss of £11,000 owing to an inorease in th9 aotive circulation, and the market resources have gained about half a million as shown by the inorease in Other Deposits. The situation is not all that oould be desired, but it is certainly improving and although we oannot look for any great ease in the immediate fataro, a slight relaxation is more than probable. The Stock Markets, A multiplicity of events have engaged the attention of members of the Stook Exohange this week. In the first place, the monthly settlements commenced on Monday, and though business daring the account had been on a limited scale, the carry-over absorbed the greater part of the time. On Wednesday thare were two important events, to wit the Derby, humorously described by Mr. Bottom- ley as a "great national festival," and the Feist of Pentecost. The Derby took many members to Epsom Downs, while the Jewish festival was responsible for the absence from the house of others who are oonneoted with the Hebrew Faith. These distraotions, aided to the near approaoh of the holidays—the Stook Exohange doses from to-night,—and the Decoration Day holiday in New York, have tended to keep dealings on a very low level. The tone of the markets his been oheerfal notwithstanding, and it is confidently expected that after the holiday ijs out of the way we shall see a revival of business. One foot which added to this feeling of oheerfalne38 was the general easing of contango rate?, this being received with much relief as higher charges were anticipated. Most of the Egyptian shares were arranged on the basis of 6 to 8%. There is little of interest to report respecting the movements of stook markets. Gilt-edged securities have been the most satisfactory section, Consols dosing appreciably higher on the week. The Consol acoount was arranged at from 31 to 4%, ft shade easier than last time. Russians have been in a miserable condition, but have now recovered somewhat, thanks to assistance from the Continent. Consols. Continued fears of trouble between the Raaaian Government and the new Parliament were the oanse of the extreme weakness of the bonds of that country In the week, the Fours dropping at one time as low as 80 j. A firmer tendency on the Paris Bourse was subsequent- ( ly favourable to thea9 bonds, which dose better at 82. The new Japanese loans are firm, bat there is little alteration in piices to note. The closing quotation for the Four per cents is 92 7/8. Egyptian Unified have advanced J. Home Ralls. The fiue weather, and the excellent pros-pects for bumper holiday traffics, have oaused some buying of home railway shares, though, actiog iu sympathy with the ganeral idleness, the movements have not bean near so satisfactory as the oatlook justified. Districts are 1 point better, and Metropolitans generally are firm, but the deferred stock i of the Southern lines have been offered. Americans, Amerioan railway shares commenced the week badly, the advices from Wall Stree being was a slight recovery, bat the holiday in New York on Wednesday has interfered with basines0, PO that the market is now idle. Illinois Central have been aotive on prospeots of a better ootton crop, and the shares are ahont 4 points up on our last quotation. Southern Paoifio and Unions ate 1/3 up. Canadian Paoifios and Erie are rather lower. Steel preference are unjhanged. Egyptians. As regards the basiness aspect, the Egyptian market is quite dead, and there does not Beam muoh prospect of things improving at present. National Bank of Egypt close rather sellers at 26, and Agricultural Banks at 9 7/8. Delta Laud and Investment have changed hands as high as 4 7/16, bat close only 4 1/8. Laud and General were also in demand, in the early part of the week, and rose to 3/16 premium buyers, but at this puce there seemed to be plenty of shares to be had, and the price soon relapsed to 1/16 sellers, closing shade harder at 1/8 premium. Union Fon- oifcre are easier at 6 j, and Abyssinian Banks are unmentionei and unohanged at par. Daira Sanieh have been up to 17 j buyers, but leave off sel'ers at this price. The Deferred are nominally 103. Daira Sugar are better at 4 $—}. Delta Preference Bearer are round about 12, and Egyptian Estates 1 $-j* There was a little business yesterday in Land Banks on the basis of 8 j—9. Bank of Rumania are easier at 9 1/3 10. Salt and Soda at 23s., Egyptian Markets at 1 and Corporation of Western Egypt at | premium are quite unchanged. Mining. The Sou4h Afrioan market shares in the general idleness, this being, of course, hut a continuation of a long-existent state of affairs. Band Mines and Bast Rands are praotioally unchanged, but Goldfields show a decline of about 3/32. Iu the Diamond group Premiers have shed j to 16 £. Bankets are offered at 2 fj. * In connection with the mining carry-over it is satisfactory to note that several of the shares show a moderate advance daring the acooant. South African Gold Mines, for inBtanoe, have risen and Band Mines East Bands are better. In the Egyptian section there has not been muoh movement since our last. Um Rus have had a set-back, on rumours of possible reconstruction, the price falling Is. lOjd. to 2s. 6d. Nile Valleys are steady at 7/6, and Block "E" are slightly better at 1. div.head: BELLA VISTA HOTEL.
div.p: This excellent hotel, which includes also a hydro-pathic establishment, is situated in thu healthiest jmrt of nuxlorn Jaffa, closo to the sea, and commands a magnificent view of tho old town. It supplies very home comfort, has a large salon and airy l- di.»oms, promenade, and a cuisine suited to all la-tes. It is within easy walking distance of the >'afion and quay. Moderate charges. I he Hydropathic Department, which is furnished Hi all necessary baths and electrical apparatus, is under the care of a skilful diplomat, physician, whose ill. ucious treatments have already rendered invaluable help to many sufferers.
